description: An ancient city that was part of the Mitanni, Hittite, and Neo-Assyrian Empires (Kargamiš in Hittite; commonly Carchemish). The site was occupied as early as the Neolithic and Chalcolithic periods; evidence for Early Bronze Age cist tombs begins ca. 2400 BC. It was a key commercial center during the time of Ebla and Mari. The Mitanni controlled the site from the sixteenth to the fourteenth centuries and was conquered by Šuppiluliuma ca. 1350 B.C. A famous battle, attested in the Bible, was fought at the site in 605 BC between the Babylonian army under Nebuchadnezzar II and that of the Egyptian Pharaoh Necho II.
details: The Barrington Atlas Directory notes: Jerablous/Cerablus (Carchemish) SYR/TKY

names.details: On the borders of the province of Cezīre: The land of Kürdistān between Dicle (Tigris) and Furāt (Euphrates) is called Cezīre. Its western boundary extends southward along the Furāt (Euphrates) to the frontier of Malāṭiyye (Malatya), then to Samsāṭ (Samosata), and to Ḳalʿatü’r-Rūm. From there, it passes on the side of Münbic (Manbij), then to Bālīs, Raḳḳa (Raqqa), Ḳarġāmış (Carchemish), Raḥbe, Hīt, and ends at Enbār. From Enbār, it continues along the Dicle (Tigris) to Tikrīt (Tikrit), then to Sin, Ḥadīs̠e, Mevṣil (Mosul), and from there, to Cezīre-i Ibn ʿÖmer (Cizre) and reaches the city of Āmid (Diyarbakır)... (partially translated by the first creator of this entry.)
